info.title: Nexus Dashboard Fabric Controller API - LAN
info.description: Nexus Dashboard Fabric Controller API - LAN

get.description: Get all the Templates.

200.description: Response body give the success

delete.description: Delete the list of given Templates.

requestBody.description: List of Template names in key value pairs. Payload is a dictionary with two keys: fabTemplate, name. fabTemplate : A list of Fabric Template names. name : A list of other Template names.  Ex: {"fabTemplate":["fabTemplate1","fabTemplate2"],"name":["otherTemplate1","otherTemplate2"]}

200.description: Response body give the success

get.description: Export the given Template.

parameters.name: template
parameters.description: Name of the Template. Ex: Default_Network_Universal

200.description: Response body is plain text of Template contents

post.description: Export selected templates in zip file format.

requestBody.description: Key value(s) pairs where key must be 'templateNames' and value(s) is comma separated template names. Ex: {"templateNames":"Default_Network_Extension_Universal,Default_Network_Universal"}

200.description: Template(s) file downloaded successfully.

post.description: Sets Git Credentials.

parameters.name: gitchanged
parameters.description: Flag if credentials are being updated

parameters.name: accesstoken
parameters.description: Git Access Token from where templates are to be uploaded

parameters.name: username
parameters.description: Git username from where templates are to be uploaded

parameters.name: password
parameters.description: Git password from where templates are to be uploaded

200.description: Git credentials were set properly

post.description:
Create a Template.
Template file contents example for sample_template. Please refer to the NDFC configuration guide for additional information. Click here
##template properties
name= sample_template;
description= ;
tags= ;
supportedPlatforms= All;
templateType= POLICY;
templateSubType= DEVICE;
contentType= TEMPLATE_CLI;
dependencies= ;
implements= ;
##template variables
#Add your variables here
@(IsMandatory=false, IsInternal=true)
string test_field;
##
##template content
#Add your template content here
##

parameters.name: templateName
parameters.description: Name of the Template. Ex . Easy_Fabric_Classic

requestBody.description: Complete Template contents. Example can be found at API description.

200.description: Response body give the success or failure message

get.description:
Query param input (optional):
    { "filter": "[field1==val1]&&[field2==val2]&&[field3~val3][...]" }

Fields and operators:  Source[equals|contains],   UserName[equals|contains],   Description[contains],   Group[equals]

where operator "equals" is "==", "contains" is "~"

parameters.description: Accounting logs filter

200.description: Response body give the success or failure message.

get.description:
Query param input (optional):
    { "filter": "[field1==val1]&&[field2==val2]&&[field3~val3][...]" }

Fields and operators:  Group[equals],   Switch[equals|contains],   Severity[equals]{Emergency|Alert|Critical|Error|Warning|Notice|Info|Debug},   Facility[equals|contains],   Type[equals|contains],   LastSeenTime[equals]{Last 10 Minutes|Lost Housr|24 Hours|Week|Month},   Description[contains],   AckUser[equals|contains]

where operator "equals" is "==", "contains" is "~"

post.description:
Create a Fabric with the given name-value pair(s). These name-value pair(s) depend on the Fabric Template selected.
Below are the types of Fabric Templates.


Data Center VXLAN EVPN (Template Name: Easy_Fabric)- Fabric for a VXLAN EVPN deployment with Nexus 9000 and 3000 Switches.
Enhanced Classic LAN (Template Name: Easy_Fabric_Classic)- Fabric for a fully automated 3-tier Classic LAN deployment with Nexus 9000
and 7000 Switches.
Campus VXLAN EVPN (Template Name: Easy_Fabric_IOS_XE)- Fabric for a VXLAN EVPN Campus deployment with Catalyst 9000 Switches.
BGP Fabric (Template Name: Easy_Fabric_eBGP)- Fabric for an eBGP based deployment with Nexus 9000 and 3000 Switches. Optionally
VXLAN EVPN can be enabled on top of the eBGP underlay.
Flexible Network (Template Name: External_Fabric)- Fabric for flexible deployments with a mix of Nexus and Non-Nexus Devices.
Fabric Group (Template Name: Fabric_Group)- Domain that can contain Enhanced Classic LAN, Classic LAN, and External
Connectivity Network Fabrics.
Classic LAN (Template Name: LAN_Classic)- Fabric to manage a legacy Classic LAN deployment with Nexus Switches.
LAN Monitor (Template Name: LAN_Monitor)- Fabric for monitoring Nexus Switches for basic discovery and Inventory management.
VXLAN EVPN Multi (Template Name: MSD_Fabric)- Site - Domain that can contain multiple VXLAN EVPN Fabrics with Layer-2/Layer-3 Overlay Extensions and other Fabric Types.
Classic IPFM (Template Name: IPFM_Classic)- Fabric to manage or monitor existing Nexus 9000 switches in an IP Fabric for Media Deployment.
IPFM (Template Name: Easy_Fabric_IPFM)- Fabric for a fully automated deployment of IP Fabric for Media Network with Nexus 9000 switches.
Multi-Site Interconnect Network (Template Name: External_Fabric)- Fabric to interconnect VXLAN EVPN fabrics for Multi-Site deployments with a mix of Nexus and Non-Nexus Devices.
External Connectivity Network (Template Name: External_Fabric)- Fabric for Core and Edge router deployments with a mix of
Nexus and Non-Nexus Devices.

parameters.name: fabricName
parameters.description: Name of the Fabric. Ex: MyFabric

parameters.name: templateName
parameters.description: Name of the Fabric Template. Ex: Easy_Fabric

parameters.name: ticketId
parameters.description: Change Control Ticket ID. This is mandatory if Change Control is enabled. Ex: MyTicket1234

requestBody.description: Name-Value pair(s) in key value format.  Ex: {"BGP_AS": "67"}

200.description: Fabric created successfully

500.description: Failed to create the Fabric with specific name-value pair(s)

requestBody.description: Name-Value pair(s) of the Fabric. Ex:{"FABRIC_TYPE":"Switch_Fabric","FABRIC_NAME":"MyFabric","BGP_AS":"67"}

200.description: Fabric updated successfully

get.description:
Get generated key for DevicePair/DeviceInterface/Link.

**Note:**

1. If type = DevicePair, Mandatory fields are: paramOne - SN1, paramTwo - SN2 

2. If type = DeviceInterface, Mandatory fields are: paramOne - SN1, paramTwo - Interface name of SN1 

3. If type = Link, Mandatory fields are: paramOne - SN1, paramTwo - Interface name of SN1, paramThree - SN2, paramFour - Interface name of SN2 

**SN1 - Serial Number of Device 1, SN2 - Serial Number of Device 2**

post.description:
Create different types of Interfaces such as *Port-channel*, *vPC*, *ST FEX*, *AA FEX*, *Loopback* and *Subinterface*.Any Interface can be added only once.

Invoking this API more than once with same payload will return error `Resource could not be allocated`. Once invoked, any further changes to Interface should be done using `PUT` API. Once the Interface is added, use `/rest/interface/deploy` API to push the config to Device.

Following are the `interfaceTypes` corresponding to each Interfaces:

1. **Port Channel** -- INTERFACE_PORT_CHANNEL
2. **virtual Port Channel (vPC)** --- INTERFACE_VPC
3. **Loopback** --- INTERFACE_LOOPBACK
4. **Straight-through (ST) FEX** --- STRAIGHT_TROUGH_FEX
5. **Active-Active (AA) FEX** --- AA_FEX
6. **Subinterface** --- SUBINTERFACE

7. **Ethernet** --- INTERFACE_ETHERNET

8. **Switch Virtual Interface (SVI)** --- INTERFACE_VLAN

For adding vPC and AA FEX, serial number should be a combined serial number Ex: FDO21331S8T~FDO21332E6X. User can get the combined serial number by using `/rest/interface/vpcpair_serial_number` REST API

parameters.name: ticketId
parameters.description: Change Control Ticket ID. This is mandatory if Change Control is enabled. Ex: MyTicket1234

requestBody.description: Interface Payload

200.description: Interfaces created successfully

500.description: Invalid payload or any other internal server error

post.description:
Generate & allocate an id resource in Resource Manager to the given Entity and returns the allocated resource id.

**Note:** 

 1. If `resourceId` is given, then the same id is allocated. Else, the next available id for the given type will be allocated.

2. If `allocatedTo` is given, then allocation happens to that Entity name. Else, Resource allocation doesn't happen but returns the next available Resource id.

200.description: Allocated the Resource id to the given Entity

400.description: Resource id not allocated due to invalid input

500.description: Other exceptions in processing the request

2. If `allocatedTo` is given, then allocation happens to that Entity name. Else, Resource allocation doesn't happen but returns the next available Resource id in response.

post.description:
Reserve Resource id in the Resource Manager to the given Entity and returns the Resource id.

**Note:** 

 1. If `resourceId` is given, then the same id is reserved. Else, the next available id for the given type will be reserved.

2. If `allocatedTo` is given, then the Resource is reserved to the given Entity. Else, Resource reservation doesn't happen but returns the next available Resource id.

200.description: Reserved the Resource id to the given Entity

400.description: Resource id is not reserved due to invalid input

500.description: Other exceptions in processing the request

post.summary: Reserve Resource id for the given Entity and return Resource Manager database id
post.description:
Reserve Resource id in the Resource Manager to the given Entity and return the Resource id & Resource Manager database id.

**Note:** 

 1. If `resourceId` is given, then the same id is reserved. Else, the next available id for the given type will be reserved.

2. If `allocatedTo` is given, then the Resource is reserved to the given Entity. Else, Resource reservation doesn't happen but returns the next available Resource id.

200.description: Reserved the Resource id to the given Entity

400.description: Resource id is not reserved due to invalid input

500.description: Other exceptions in processing the request

delete.description: Release the Resources based on given Resource Manager database id.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Resource manager database ids separated by comma (Check and get the database ids for the choosed Fabric from API: '/appcenter/cisco/ndfc/api/v1/lan-fabric/rest/resource-manager/fabrics/{fabricName}'). Ex: 40,48

200.description: Resource allocation is released successfully

400.description: Resource not released due to invalid input

500.description: Other exceptions in processing the request

post.description:
Allocate the SUBNET/IP Resource from the Resource Pool and returns the allocated Resource & respective Resource Manager database id.

Following are the `Pool Types` corresponding to poolnames:

1. **SUBNET_POOL** -- SUBNET, DCI subnet pool.
2. **IP_POOL** -- LOOPBACK0_IP_POOL, LOOPBACK1_IP_POOL, ANYCAST_RP_IP_POOL, MPLS_LOOPBACK_IP_POOL, MCAST_IP_POOL.

**Note:** Get the Resource Pool details using the Pool name from the API: '/appcenter/cisco/ndfc/api/v1/lan-fabric/rest/resource-manager/fabric/{fabricName}/pools'.

requestBody.description: IP Resource usage data

200.description: Allocated the IP/SUBNET Resource form the Resource Pool successfully

400.description: IP/SUBNET Resource not allocated due to invalid input

500.description: Other exceptions in processing the request

delete.description: Release the IP/SUBNET Resource allocation for the given Resource Manager database id(s).

parameters.name: rmid
parameters.description: Resource manager database ids separated by comma (Check and get the database ids for the choosed Fabric from API: '/appcenter/cisco/ndfc/api/v1/lan-fabric/rest/resource-manager/fabrics/{fabricName}'). Ex: 28,32

200.description: The IP/SUBNET Resource allocation is released successfully

400.description: Resource not released due to invalid input

500.description: Other exceptions in processing the request

post.summary: Bulk import of flow policies into the given fabric
post.description:
Import multiple flow policies into the given fabric. Input should be in CSV format. The first line in the input should be headers - Policy Name, VRF, Multicast IP Range, Bandwidth, DSCP, and Policer - followed by multiple flow policy entries on separate lines. 

Note: The import functionality cannot be used to update existing policies. Only new entries can be added. 

Description of headers: 
- Policy Name - Name of the policy. Name cannot contain '-' or ':' or '<' or '>' or ' ' (space) characters. 
- VRF - Name of the VRF that the policy belongs to. This field is optional and if it is omitted, 'default' VRF is assumed. 
- Multicast IP Range - Multiple ranges in the format beginIP-endIP-flowPriority separated by semi-colon (;).  Both endIP and flowPriority can be omitted, and only one IP can be provided. FlowPriority value can be 'Critical' or 'Default' and defaults to 'Default' when omitted. For example,  224.5.5.10-224.5.5.50-Critical; 224.5.5.60-224.5.5.93; or 226.8.8.8 or 226.8.8.8-Default. 
- Bandwidth - Bandwidth value and units for the flow, for example, 2.1 Mbps or 1 Kbps or 3gbps. 
- DSCP - String value or numeric value for DSCP, for example, CS1 or 8. 
- Policer - Optional string value, for example, "enabled" or "disabled". Defaults to "enabled" if not provided.

parameters.name: fabricName
parameters.description: Name of the fabric that the Flow Policy belongs to

200.description: Flow Policy import successfully done ...

403.description: Operation is not allowed in read-only mode

500.description: Message varies depending on the condition

post.summary: Undeploy one or more flow policies
post.description:
Undeploy (remove) one or more flow policies from the devices in the given fabric, based on the list of Policy Names (optionally, the list of Switch IPs) provided.  
If Switch IPs are not provided, policies will be undeployed from all the switches in the fabric.  
The policy name should be prefixed by the VRF name seperated by colon, e.g. VRF1:policy1,VRF2:policy2. If VRF name and the delimiter (:) are omitted, 'default' VRF is assumed.  
In case of default policy, it will not be removed from the device but will be reset to have default values (Bandwidth: 0gbps, DSCP: Best Effort, Policer: Enabled).

parameters.name: fabricName
parameters.description: Name of the fabric that the flow policies belong to

schema.description:
Example Request Body: 
{ "policyNames":["VRF1:POLICY_NAME_1","VRF2:POLICY_NAME_2","POLICY_NAME_3"], "switchIps": ["1.1.1.1","2.2.2.2"]}

200.description: Flow Policy Undeployment Started for ...

post.summary: Bulk import of host policies into the given fabric
post.description:
Import multiple host policies into the given fabric. Input should be in CSV format. The first line in the input should be headers - Policy Name,VRF,Multicast IP/Mask,Receiver IP,Sender IP,Host Role,Operation,Sequence # - followed by multiple host policy entries on separate lines. 

Note: The import functionality cannot be used for updating existing policies. Only new entries can be added. 

Description of headers: 
- Policy Name - Name of the policy. Name cannot contain ':' or '<' or '>' or ' ' (space) characters. 
- VRF - Name of the VRF that the policy belongs to. This field is optional and if it is omitted, 'default' VRF is assumed.
- Multicast IP/Mask -  Valid multicast in the in range 224.0.0.0 - 239.255.255.255. Enter \* or 0.0.0.0 for any multicast. Default mask (32) is considered if no value for mask is provided.  Example, 224.5.5.5 or 224.5.5.5/24. The server property 'Enable mask/prefix for the multicast range in Host Policy' needs to be enabled to be able to provide a mask/prefix. 
- Receiver IP - IP of the receiver host. Required only in case the role is Receiver-Local. 
- Sender IP - IP of the sender host (source). Enter \* or 0.0.0.0 for any IP in case the role is Receiver-Local or Receiver-External.  
- Host Role - Sender, Receiver-Local, or Receiver-External. 
- Operation - Permit or Deny. 
- Sequence # - User-provided sequence number of the policy. Required only if 'Enable mask/prefix for the multicast range in Host Policy' property is enabled. This header can be omitted if DCNM-generated sequence numbers are to be used.

parameters.name: fabricName
parameters.description: Name of the fabric that the Host Policy belongs to

schema.description:
Example Request Body (make sure each entry starts on a new line): 

 Policy Name,VRF,Multicast IP / Mask,Receiver IP,Sender IP,Host Role,Operation 
 Policy1,default,224.4.4.4/32,1.1.1.1,2.2.2.2,Receiver-Local,Permit  
 Policy2,vrf1,*,,3.3.3.3,Sender,Deny  
 Policy3,,225.5.5.5/32,,2.2.2.2,Receiver-External,Permit

200.description:
If specific policies are imported, response will contain the imported polciy details and any erros as shown below: 
 {"imports":[{"hostPolicyId": POLICY_ID, "host": "HOST_NAME", "receiverIp":"RECEIVER_IP","senderIp":"SENDER_IP","multicast": "MULTICAST_IP", "mask":MASK,"hostRole": "Sender|Receiver-External|Receiver-Local", "permit": true|false, "sequenceNumber":SEQUENCE_NUMBER, "createdBy": "USER_NAME", "lastUpdated": LAST_UPDATED_TIMESTAMP, "devicesAppliedTo": [ {"switchName": "SWITCH_NAME_1", "ifName": "INTERFACE_NAME_1"}, {"switchName": "SWITCH_NAME_2", "ifName": "INTERFACE_NAME_2"}], "policyName": "POLICY_NAME", "lastUpdatedAsString": "LAST_UPDATED_TIME_AS_STRING"}],"errors":["Skipping import of policy '<POLICY_NAME>' as it is already present and cannot be imported"]}

403.description: Operation is not allowed in read-only mode

post.summary: Undeploy one or more host policies
post.description:
Undeploy (remove) one or more host policies from the devices in the given fabric, based on the list of Policy Names (optionally, a list of Switch IPs) provided.  
If Switch IPs are not provided, policies will be undeployed from all the switches in the fabric.  
The policy name should be prefixed by the VRF name seperated by colon, e.g. VRF1:policy1,VRF2:policy2. If VRF name and the delimiter (:) are omitted, 'default' VRF is assumed.  
In case of default policies, policies are not removed but they will be reset to have default permission (Allow).

parameters.name: fabricName
parameters.description: Name of the fabric that the host policies belong to

schema.description:
Example Request Body: 
{ "policyNames":["VRF1:POLICY_NAME_1","VRF2:POLICY_NAME_2","POLICY_NAME_3"], "switchIps": ["1.1.1.1","2.2.2.2"]}

post.summary: Create a new Flow Policy in the given fabric and the VRF
post.description:
Creates a new flow policy in the given fabric and the VRF 

Description of Fields: 
- policyName - Name of the policy. Name cannot contain '-' or ':' or '<' or '>' or ' ' (space) characters. 
- bandwidth - Bandwidth value and units provided as one string, for example, 3gbps, 1.2mbps, or 2kbps.
- dscp - String value or numeric value for DSCP, for example, "CS1", "8", or 8. 
- policer - Optional string value, for example, "enabled" or "disabled". Defaults to "enabled" if not provided.  
- multicastRangeList - List of multicast ranges in the format  [{"beginIP": "224.0.0.1", "endIP": "224.0.0.10", "flowPriority": "Default"},{"beginIP": "225.2.0.1", "endIP": "225.2.0.10", "flowPriority": "Critical"}]. endIP can be omitted if it is not a range. FlowPriority is a string value - Critical or Default. FlowPriority defaults to 'Default' when omitted.

parameters.name: fabricName
parameters.description: Name of the fabric that the Flow Policy belongs to

parameters.name: vrfName
parameters.description: Name of the VRF that the Flow Policy belongs to

schema.description:
Example Request Body for Creation: 

{"policyName": "POLICY_NAME", "bandwidth":"3gbps", "dscp": "8", "policer": "enabled", "multicastRangeList":[ {"beginIP": "224.0.0.1", "endIP": "224.0.0.10", "flowPriority": "Default"},{"beginIP": "225.2.0.1", "endIP": "225.2.0.10", "flowPriority": "Critical"}]}

202.description:
Returns the Flow Policy details. Example Response Body: 
 {"flowPolicyId": FLOW_POLICY_ID, 
"multicastRangeList":[ {"beginIP": "224.0.0.1", "endIP": "224.0.0.10", "flowPriority": "DEFAULT"},{"beginIP": "225.2.0.1", "endIP": "225.2.0.10", "flowPriority": "CRITICAL"}], 
"bandwidth": "BANDWIDTH_AND_UNITS_IN_TEXT", 
"dscp": "DSCP_VALUE", 
"policer": "Enabled/Disabled", 
"createdBy": "USER_NAME", 
"lastUpdated": LAST_UPDATED_TIMESTAMP, 
"policyName": "POLICY_NAME", 
"fabric": "FABRIC", 
"vrf": "VRF", 
"strBandwidth": "BANDWIDTH_VALUE_IN_TEXT", 
"unit": "BANDWIDTH_UNIT", 
"inUse": true|false, 
"lastUpdateAsString": "LAST_UPDATED_TIME_IN_TEXT"}

post.summary: Create a new Host Policy in the given fabric and the VRF
post.description:
Create a new host policy in the given fabric and the VRF. 

Description of Fields: 
- policyName - Name of the policy. Name cannot contain ':' or '<' or '>' or ' ' (space) characters. 
- multicast - Valid multicast in the range 224.0.0.0 - 239.255.255.255. Enter \* or 0.0.0.0 for any multicast. 
- mask - Required only to provide non-default (32) mask. Otherwise, it can be omitted. 
- receiverIp - IP of the receiver host. Required only in case the role is Receiver-Local. Otherwise, it can be omitted.  
- senderIp - IP of the sender host (source). Enter \* or 0.0.0.0 for any sender IP. 
- hostRole - Sender, Receiver-Local, or Receiver-External. 
- permit - true or false. 
- sequenceNumber - User-provided sequence number of the policy. Required only if the 'Enable mask/prefix for the multicast range in Host Policy' property is enabled. Can be omitted if DCNM-generated sequence numbers are to be used.

parameters.name: fabricName
parameters.description: Name of the fabric that the Host Policy belongs to

parameters.name: vrfName
parameters.description: Name of the VRF that the Host Policy belongs to

schema.description:

post.description:
Import multiple Multicast NAT Modes into the given switch. Input should be in CSV format. The first line in the input should be headers - VRF,Group,Mode - followed by multiple Multicast NAT Mode entries on separate lines. 

Note: The import functionality cannot be used for updating existing Multicast NAT Modes. Only new entries can be added. 

Description of headers:

- Mode - Ingress or Egress.

post.summary: Import the security contract associations in bulk
post.description:
Create the security contract associations in bulk via CSV file import. To get the correct format of the CSV file, please download the sample file from the UI as follows:
Go to the specific Fabric, click on Security -> Associations -> Action -> Export to get the CSV formatted file. Please use Excel to edit or modify data to ensure data is formatted correctly.
First line must be the headers. Each data row must be in a new line. Data elements within a row must be comma separated.
Example:
ContractName,SourceGroup,SGT,DestinationGroup,DGT,VRF
Contract1,SG_10000,10000,SG_10001,10001,myvrf_50000

post.summary: Import the security protocols in bulk
post.description:
Create the security protocols in bulk via CSV file import. To get the correct format of the CSV file, please download the sample file from the UI as follows:
Go to the specific Fabric, click on Security -> Protocols -> Action -> Export to get the CSV formatted file. Please use Excel to edit or modify data to ensure data is formatted correctly.
First line must be the headers. Each data row must be in a new line. Data elements within a row must be comma separated.
Example:
Name,Description,Type,IPProtocol,SourcePortRange,DestinationPortRange,TCPSessionRules,Dscp,OnlyFragments,Stateful
icmp,Match ICMP (auto generated),IP,ICMP,,,,,,

tags.description: The second step of L4-L7 services flow, i.e. service cluster's logical attachments to VXLAN EVPN fabric

tags.description: The fourth step of L4-L7 services flow, i.e. service chain for traffic redirect
